data.title: Kurt Cobain’s Death Reviewed by Cold-Case Detective; New Photo to Be Released Later Today
data.meta_description: As the 20th anniversary of Kurt Cobain’s tragic death approaches, Seattle police confirm that they have reviewed the late Nirvana front man’s case file.
data.text:
As the 20th anniversary of Kurt Cobain’s tragic death approaches, Seattle police confirm that they have reviewed the late Nirvana front man’s file, as they are “anticipating questions surrounding the closed Cobain case.” The police department also clarified that it has not re-opened the investigation, as was erroneously reported earlier this morning.

Confusion over the status of the investigation was sparked today when police spokeswoman Renee Witt alerted news organizations that a cold-case detective “dug up the files and had another look,” however the detective determined that “there was nothing new” to the case. Additionally, Witt revealed that the detective discovered rolls of undeveloped film from the death scene. However, once the film was developed, the detective determined that “[t]here was nothing earth-shattering in any of these images.” Regardless, the A.P. reports that police plan to release at least one of the recovered photos to the public later today and answer questions about Cobain’s death.

The tragic milestone arrives early next month. Cobain’s body was found inside his Seattle greenhouse on April 8, 1994. Per the A.P., “an investigation determined that days earlier Cobain had gone into the greenhouse of his large home and taken a massive dose of heroin. He then shot himself with a 20-gauge shotgun. Earlier that year Cobain had tried to kill himself in Rome by taking an overdose of tranquilizers.”

In other Cobain news, a group of fans led by journalist Jaime Dunkle are attempting to crowdsource $700,000 to purchase the late musician’s childhood home in Aberdeen, Washington, and convert it into a museum. In the same town, last month, fans were confused when Cobain was memorialized with a bizarre statue of the musician crying. On April 10 next month, the band will get a more proper tribute when it is formally inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

Politics

The Case for Kamala Harris

Replacing Joe Biden would be risky. But it may be the best chance the Democrats have to protect democracy from Donald Trump.

Hollywood

Alec Baldwin's Involuntary Manslaughter Case Has Been Dismissed

The prosecution's mishandling of evidence led the judge to halt the actor's trial in the Rust movie shooting that killed cinematographer Halyna Hutchins.

Politics

Joe Biden Loyalists Make the Case for Gutting It Out

In the wake of last week’s disastrous debate, many Democrats are ready to risk it all on a new candidate. But some party insiders argue that, with democracy itself on the line, the smart move is to close ranks behind Biden and fight the real enemy: Donald Trump.

Hollywood

Meet the Death-Defying Couple Who Fell in Love While Climbing Skyscrapers

Angela Nikolau and Ivan Beerkus’s risky romance is the subject of Netflix documentary Skywalkers: A Love Story, previewed exclusively below.

Television

House of the Dragon’s Tom Glynn-Carney Thinks King Aegon Is a “Tragic Case”

In episode five of House of the Dragon’s second season, Team Black mourns the loss of a matriarch, while Team Green decides who will temporarily rule King’s Landing. Tom Glynn-Carney drops by Still Watching to chat about Aegon’s “boyish vulnerability” and the joy of dragon riding.

Politics

The Biden Campaign Needs to Stop Dismissing Critics as “Bed Wetters”

The president is right that his opponent represents a grave threat to American democracy. So why are his surrogates mocking the people who are taking that danger seriously?

Royals

Prince Harry “Immensely Grateful” as Founding Invictus Games CEO Steps Down

Dominic Reid is leaving the organization after 10 years.

Award Season

Baby Reindeer’s Jessica Gunning Never Saw Martha as a Villain

“She’s so much more than that,” says the newly minted Emmy nominee of her breakout role in the Netflix hit series.

Politics

As Donald Trump’s Prospects Soar, Ivanka Inches Back to the National Stage

Sources say Ivanka will attend next week’s Republican National Convention in Milwaukee—a dramatic turnaround after skipping Trump’s campaign launch and criminal trial.

Politics

Donald Trump Picks Ohio Senator J.D. Vance as His Vice Presidential Nominee

The Hillbilly Elegy author and Ohio Senator once reportedly feared Trump would be “America’s Hitler,” but has since emerged as a fierce defender of the former president and inheritor of the MAGA mantle.
